title: R for HTA in LMICs
text: üëâ Reserve Your Spot

title: About R-HTA
text:
R-HTA is a consortium focused on promoting the use of R for health economics and health technology assessment (HTA). The R for HTA in LMICs chapter is dedicated to introducing and showcasing the strengths of R programming to HTA analysts and healthcare institutions in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). It hosts an annual workshop and quarterly tutorials, providing a platform where LMIC students and members of partner organisations can present their work, share experiences, and learn a wide range of R-based public health analysis techniques.



To empower LMIC (low- and middle-income countries) health systems with cutting-edge, reproducible, and accessible analytical tools for HTA using the R language.
Learn more about our workshops and learning resources designed to build skills for both beginners and experienced practitioners.




The R-HTA in LMICs chapter is the regional arm of the R-HTA consortium. Its mission is to:

Introduce R as a viable alternative to costly software
Support LMIC analysts and institutions in adopting R for HTA
Share tailored educational resources and workshops

We believe that open-source tools like R can help bridge the digital and economic divide in health analysis, fostering a community that thrives on collaboration and shared innovation.




HTA in LMICs is often constrained by: - Heavy reliance on proprietary software like Microsoft Excel and TreeAge - Limited budgets and access to advanced tools - Lack of hands-on, practical R training for HTA analysts
Meanwhile, health systems in LMICs are rapidly evolving, especially under the drive toward Universal Health Coverage (UHC). This creates a growing need for: - Complex modelling (e.g.¬†oncology, rare diseases) - Scalable and reproducible tools - Local capacity-building
Contact us to discuss how we can help bring these capabilities to your institution.





Workshops & Training Opportunities ‚Äî covering R, Health Technology Assessment (HTA), essential R packages, and practical tips for applying R in diverse contexts. Explore more on our Workshops page.
Advanced tutorials ‚Äî building cost-effectiveness models and interactive apps using Shiny.
Free resources and code ‚Äî all available on our GitHub.

We work side-by-side with partners, offering mentoring, technical assistance, and bespoke solutions for regional health needs.




Scalable
R handles complex HTA models more efficiently than spreadsheet-based tools. Read more
Reproducible
With Git, RMarkdown, and Shiny, models can be: - Shared with version control - Easily updated - Delivered as interactive tools
Open and Community-Driven
R‚Äôs vibrant health economics ecosystem includes: - BCEA - heemod - hesim - dampack




We welcome collaborators and learners alike‚Äîjoin us in building a stronger foundation for HTA in LMICs using R.
Visit our contact page to connect with our team.

title: About
text:
R-HTA in LMICs is a focused chapter of the R-HTA consortium that aims to democratize access to health economic modeling tools by promoting the use of R among analysts and institutions in Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs).
We envision a world where HTA capacity in LMICs is strengthened through open-source tools, local knowledge-sharing, and equitable access to technical resources.

title: About
text:
In many LMICs, HTA models continue to rely on tools like Microsoft Excel or TreeAge‚Äîsoftware that may be limited in scalability, transparency, and cost-effectiveness.
The R-HTA in LMICs chapter was created to address key challenges:

üí∞ High licensing costs for traditional HTA software
üåç Growing demand for complex modeling with the rise of Universal Health Coverage (UHC)
üìö Limited local training in open-source HTA solutions

We provide targeted resources, training, and community support to help LMIC analysts transition from proprietary platforms to R‚Äîan efficient, reproducible, and cost-free solution.

title: About R-HTA
text:
Workshops & Training Opportunities ‚Äî covering R, Health Technology Assessment (HTA), essential R packages, and practical tips for applying R in diverse contexts. Explore more on our Workshops page.
Advanced tutorials ‚Äî building cost-effectiveness models and interactive apps using Shiny.
Free resources and code ‚Äî all available on our GitHub.

We work side-by-side with partners, offering mentoring, technical assistance, and bespoke solutions for regional health needs.

title: About
text:
As HTA models grow more detailed‚Äîe.g.¬†in oncology or rare diseases‚ÄîR outperforms spreadsheet-based approaches in speed, clarity, and scalability. Read more.



R‚Äôs growing ecosystem includes many powerful HTA packages: - heemod - hesim - BCEA - dampack




Projects can be shared and version-controlled using GitHub
Updates won‚Äôt ‚Äúbreak‚Äù models thanks to structured environments
Results can be published as transparent reports via Quarto, R Markdown, and Shiny


We welcome collaborators and learners alike‚Äîjoin us in building a stronger foundation for HTA in LMICs using R.

title: Meet the R-HTA in LMICs Committee ü§ù
text:
‚ÄúThe R-HTA in LMICs team comprises individuals from a range of Lower-Middle Income Countries (LMICs). We have a diverse set of skills and backgrounds and hope to share our experiences in learning R for HTA with you!‚Äù

We are a growing team of researchers, economists, data scientists, and public health professionals who are passionate about improving healthcare decision-making in LMICs through open-source tools and collaborative learning.

title: R for HTA in LMICs
text:
We focus on three key areas to support the HTA community:

Tutorials
Practical, hands-on training in R for health economic modeling and analysis.
Resources
Curated open-source tools, guides, and references tailored for HTA professionals.
Events
Workshops and webinars led by international experts in R and HTA.

title: Meet the R-HTA in LMICs Committee
text:
Meet the R-HTA in LMICs Committee
The R-HTA in LMICs team comprises individuals from Lower-Middle Income Countries with diverse backgrounds passionate about improving healthcare decision-making through open-source tools and collaborative learning.

Co-Chairs








Buhle Ndweni


Lecturer in Health Economics


Buhle is a PhD candidate at the University of Cape Town and founding director of R-HTA in LMICs. She‚Äôs passionate about health economics and equitable access to care across Africa.












Joshua Soboil


Health Economist


Joshua is a health economist focused on evidence synthesis and decision modeling in LMICs. He co-founded the R-HTA in LMICs group.








Scientific Committee Members








Carina Behr


PhD Candidate


Carina is a health economist with a background in industrial engineering. Her expertise lie in complex simulation modelling. She holds a BSc and an MSc in Industrial engineering from the University of Pretoria and University of Twente, respectively.












Islem Meherzi


Data Science Engineer


Islem Meherzi is a Senior Data Science and Research Engineer with over 7 years of experience, specializing in healthcare data solutions.












Satoshi Koiso, MDP, BVSc


Research Specialist


Satoshi Koiso is a research specialist with expertise in health policy and decision analyses, focusing on simulation modeling and cost-effectiveness evaluations.












Hannibal Musarurwa


Senior Lecturer


Senior Lecturer, Medical Biochemistry, Walter Sisulu UniversitySenior Lecturer, Medical Biochemistry, Walter Sisulu University.












Federico Rodriguez Cairoli


Medical Doctor


HTA researcher with a focus on pharmacoeconomics and epidemiology at IECS.

title: Learning Resources
text:
üìö Books & References


Recommended books for HTA using R



R for Health Technology Assessment: A comprehensive guide to the end-to-end use of R in health technology assessment (HTA), covering survival analysis, decision trees, multistate models, network meta-analysis, and discrete event simulation ‚Äî all explained through real-world examples with annotated R code. Ideal for HTA modellers, regulators, and health economists, enriched with case studies contributed by community members.

Authors: Gianluca Baio, Howard Thom, Petros Pechlivanoglou


Our Community Contributors: Buhle Ndweni, Joshua Soboil, Federico Cairoli






üî∞ Basic R


Introduction to R programming and scripting



Intro2R script: Input/output and object manipulation


Intro tutorial materials: Hands-on R learning materials from the June workshop





üîÅ Intermediate Modelling


Modeling tools based on DARTH group‚Äôs materials



Time-Dependent Models paper (2022): Introduction to time-dependent decision models


Simulation script: R script for simulating time-dependent models


State-residence time model: Simulating state-residence times


Functions for analysis: R functions used for HTA model simulations





üöÄ Advanced & Interactive Modelling


Advanced models and Shiny apps



Advanced HIV Markov model in R: Full workflow of a health economic Markov model


Explore interactive app: Interactive HIV model using Shiny





üìò Additional Resources


Recommended open learning materials



DARTH Decision Modeling Course: Free online course in health decision modeling


ISPOR Modeling Guidelines: Modeling practices and HTA methodology


Decision Modelling in Health Economic Evaluation (book): Key textbook for HTA decision modeling

üìö Books & References

R for Health Technology Assessment: A comprehensive guide to the end-to-end use of R in health technology assessment (HTA), covering survival analysis, decision trees, multistate models, network meta-analysis, and discrete event simulation ‚Äî all explained through real-world examples with annotated R code. Ideal for HTA modellers, regulators, and health economists, enriched with case studies contributed by community members.

Authors: Gianluca Baio, Howard Thom, Petros Pechlivanoglou


Our Community Contributors: Buhle Ndweni, Joshua Soboil, Federico Cairoli

title: About R-HTA in LMICs
text:
R-HTA is a consortium focused on promoting the use of R for health economics and health technology assessment (HTA). While its core members are from the Americas and the UK‚Äîrepresenting government institutions like NICE, academia, and industry‚ÄîR-HTA aims to serve a global community of analysts.



To empower LMIC (low- and middle-income countries) health systems with cutting-edge, reproducible, and accessible analytical tools for HTA using the R language.
Learn more about our workshops and learning resources designed to build skills for both beginners and experienced practitioners.




The R-HTA in LMICs chapter is the regional arm of the R-HTA consortium. Its mission is to: - Introduce R as a viable alternative to costly software - Support LMIC analysts and institutions in adopting R for HTA - Share tailored educational resources and workshops
We believe that open-source tools like R can help bridge the digital and economic divide in health analysis, fostering a community that thrives on collaboration and shared innovation.




HTA in LMICs is often constrained by: - Heavy reliance on proprietary software like Microsoft Excel and TreeAge - Limited budgets and access to advanced tools - Lack of hands-on, practical R training for HTA analysts
Meanwhile, health systems in LMICs are rapidly evolving, especially under the drive toward Universal Health Coverage (UHC). This creates a growing need for: - Complex modelling (e.g.¬†oncology, rare diseases) - Scalable and reproducible tools - Local capacity-building
Contact us to discuss how we can help bring these capabilities to your institution.





Workshops & Training Opportunities ‚Äî covering R, Health Technology Assessment (HTA), essential R packages, and practical tips for applying R in diverse contexts. Explore more on our Workshops page.
Advanced tutorials ‚Äî building cost-effectiveness models and interactive apps using Shiny.
Free resources and code ‚Äî all available on our GitHub.

We work side-by-side with partners, offering mentoring, technical assistance, and bespoke solutions for regional health needs.




Scalable
R handles complex HTA models more efficiently than spreadsheet-based tools. Read more
Reproducible
With Git, RMarkdown, and Shiny, models can be: - Shared with version control - Easily updated - Delivered as interactive tools
Open and Community-Driven
R‚Äôs vibrant health economics ecosystem includes: - BCEA - heemod - hesim - dampack




We welcome collaborators and learners alike‚Äîjoin us in building a stronger foundation for HTA in LMICs using R.
Visit our contact page to connect with our team.
